awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Did Mantle Magmas Cause Ultrahigh-Temperature Metamorphism (UHTM) in Southern Madagascar?
awd_abstract_narration:
The collision of Earth’s continents, as a result of plate tectonics, causes the crust to thicken, buckle, and become hotter, leading to lasting transformations: metamorphic mineral reactions, the formation of magma, and the reorganization of elements throughout the Earth’s crust. These processes that permanently alter the continents are most extreme in ultrahigh-temperature metamorphic (UHTM) rocks, where temperatures exceeded 900 °C. Recognizing these transformations in rocks from the Earth’s past is fundamental to understanding how the continents have changed through time. Yet, why UHTM occurs in some continental collision zones, but not others, remains unknown. This project will address the unresolved question of how and why rocks reach such ultrahigh temperatures by investigating the UHTM rocks exposed in southern Madagascar. Specifically, this work will test the hypothesis that magmas ascended from Earth’s mantle and heated the rocks of southern Madagascar to temperatures exceeding those of typical mountain belts, causing UHTM. Age dating and chemical analyses of the mineral zircon will establish the timing and origins of magma intrusions, respectively, to determine their relationship to UHTM. This project will support graduate student education at Woods Hole Oceanographic Institution and the University of Michigan, and will include cross-cultural collaboration among scientists from the U.S., Switzerland, and Madagascar. In partnership with a local organization, it provides employment and rehabilitation opportunities for disabled individuals in Massachusetts. In addition, a hands-on education project will encourage underrepresented minority students to participate in the geosciences.

This collaborative project will test the hypothesis that sizable plutons (the origins and ages of which are unknown) were the principal heat source responsible for UHTM in southern Madagascar, an archetypal UHTM terrane formed during the Late Neoproterozoic to Early Cambrian assembly of Gondwana. Prior research suggests that conductive, mechanical, and radiogenic heat sources combined were incapable of raising mid-crustal temperatures to >900 °C, so mantle magmas may be the missing heat source. Zircon Hf, delta 18O, and U-Pb ages, combined with whole rock major- and trace-element data, will be used to constrain the proportion of mantle versus crustal melts in the major plutonic suites in southern Madagascar and estimate the magmatic flux. Additional zircon and monazite analyses in host gneisses will establish whether magmatism and UHTM were contemporaneous. By resolving the timescale and extent of mantle heat advection, these results will test whether there was a causal link between magmatism and regional UHTM. In doing so, this study will enhance understanding of the regional heat budget and provide a comprehensive U-Pb zircon dataset for southern Madagascar. The results will have direct implications for coeval UHTM events recorded in Sri Lanka, India, and Antarctica, and will inform our understanding of Phanerozoic collisional orogens in general. Additionally, this project will develop dual-multicollector laser ablation split stream ICPMS techniques that will enable simultaneous measurement of Hf and U-Pb isotopes on multicollector instruments.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Continent-continent collisions are a spectacular consequence of plate tectonics, producing Himalaya-type mountain belts called collisional orogens. Earth history is punctuated by these events, which have profoundly affected the continental crust, global topography, volcanism, carbon cycling, and weather patterns. The contraction of continents when they collide creates relatively thick and cold crust. So, an enduring mystery---important for our understanding of why continents and mountain ranges persist on Earth---is why and how some rocks within collisional orogens become extremely hot. Rocks that undergo extreme heating metamorphose and melt, obscuring the geologic record of the extreme heating events. As a result, the highest temperature processes in the continents are among the least understood.

The aim of this project was to test hypotheses about the causes of extreme heating in an ancient and archetypal Himalaya-type collisional orogen by studying rocks that were once buried tens of kilometers belowground but are now exposed in Madagascar. Comparable rocks in modern collisional orogens are inaccessible. In southern Madagascar, an ultrahigh-temperature (greater than 900 degrees celsius) metamorphic terrane records extreme heating, the causes of which remained controversial. Previous studies suggested that frictional heating and the radioactive decay of naturally occurring elements were insufficient to explain such high temperatures. This project tested the alternative hypothesis that magmas from the underlying mantle transferred enough heat into the crust to cause ultrahigh-temperature metamorphism.

Intellectual outcomes: The primary outcomes of this project were threefold. First, a detailed investigation of the heating event that affected southern Madagascar rocks constrained the changes in pressure and temperature over time within the ancient collisional orogen. This provided important geologic context for understanding different heating mechanisms, which have different effects on pressure and temperature. Second, a regional synthesis of published and newly reported metamorphic mineral data enabled a four-dimensional (3-D over time) reconstruction of the ancient orogen. This part of the study utilized the composition of the mineral monazite, which exists in many crustal rocks and can be dated accurately using the U-Pb method. Importantly, the reconstruction of the orogen demonstrated that the southern Madagascar rocks were structurally confined beneath the central part of the orogen, where they could escape neither vertically nor horizontally to cooler regions. Therefore, structural trapping, in addition to focused heating, may be an important prerequisite for extreme heating in contractional tectonic settings. Third, the analysis of the mineral zircon in that grew in magmas originating from beneath the orogen decisively demonstrates that the magmas were not the cause of extreme crustal heating. The magmatic rocks have crustal, rather than mantle, isotopic affinities and crystallized tens of millions of years before the extreme heating event. Collectively, observations from across southern Madagascar can be explained by the foundering (or sinking) of the underlying lithospheric (or solid) mantle, which amplified heat transfer into the base of the crust via conduction. This foundering event can explain the melting of the lower crust to produce magmas and the subsequent extreme heating in the middle crust caused by a wave of mantle heat diffusing upward. Foundering may also play a key role during crustal heating in collisional orogens elsewhere.

Broader Impacts outcomes: This project supported two early career scientists, helping them establish their research programs. It also supported and provided fieldwork experience for two graduate students; their contributions to this project formed the basis for much of a PhD thesis and a complete MS thesis. Additionally, this project facilitated ongoing international collaborations.
